2856.61.text:
QUESTION: Yes. (OFF-MIKE) ...worked in government
for four years and the State Department. So

2861.40.text:
I'm familiar with some of the issues that
were raised about government employees making

2866.81.text:
relatively little and then making more or
at least having a comfortable retirement.

2871.42.text:
I would like to go back to a point that was
made early in the conversation about the role

2876.33.text:
of the Federal government. And at this point,
we obviously can't come to one decision as

2881.25.text:
to an overall, all-encompassing plan. But
what process -- if you were to try to sort

2888.14.text:
out with all these agencies that are involved
and all the states and all the sub-entities

2892.53.text:
in the states, how would the Federal government
proceed in trying to develop an orderly process

2899.28.text:
for adjusting this problem, for addressing
these various aspects of the problem?

2905.69.text:
Because orderly decision-making, as Glenn
knows very well -- and Brad and I have worked

2912.58.text:
on many of these issues -- orderly decision-making
is not really a hallmark of the way Washington

2918.65.text:
works on complicated issues. And I'd be very
curious as to what recommendations the panel

2924.52.text:
has on what the government, if it decided
that this was a problem, needed to be adjusted

2930.54.text:
on a more comprehensive basis with some consistency
among various entities and our federal system

2937.06.text:
-- how would the government go about addressing
this? How -- what would be the process for

2942.21.text:
getting to a rational, mutually-consistent
-- not perfect among all states, but at least

2948.95.text:
mutually-consistent set of guidelines for
moving forward?

2956.98.text:
BELT: Well, Bob, one thing that I've suggested
in the past and written about is the need

2960.98.text:
to establish at the federal level, for lack
of a better term, a national retirement securities

2967.23.text:
czar or office of requirement security policy
within the executive branch. That nominally

2973.93.text:
falls within the purview of the National Economic
Council right now. But I think the issues

2979.63.text:
are too important. And the -- and the NEC
is not I think constituted to really address

2985.36.text:
those issues optimally. We've both dealt with
those organizations.

2989.75.text:
So if you had an office of national security
policy whose sole mandate was to coordinate

2997.02.text:
at least at the national or federal level
retirement security policy against all the

3001.84.text:
different agencies and executive branch entities
that touch upon requirement security policy,

3007.97.text: that would be a starting point.

3009.84.text:
STRINGER: Maybe this is simple. But one of
the best meetings I've ever attended in my

3016.21.text:
time in government was a meeting months ago
at the White House. Our -- our office is looking

3023.33.text:
at ways to engage more managers of color.
People of all different backgrounds should

3028.45.text:
have the opportunity to manage money in our
pension fund. Most of the investors, quite

3034.03.text:
frankly, look like me, though they wear better
suits. And we need to have a more impactful

3041.08.text:
way to engage people in small funds with different
diverse backgrounds. Studies show that when

3046.26.text:
different people get to manage our pension
funds, we do better.

3049.79.text:
So the fact that I was able to go to the White
House and sit with SecretaryJarrett -- Labor

3054.87.text:
Secretary Valerie Jarrett to just have a discussion
about how we do this with other people around

3061.02.text:
the country was just so important. It's a
meeting that took six years in the making.

3067.03.text:
But it certainly energized the conversation.
You know, whoever gets elected president,

3072.68.text:
whoever controls Congress, sometimes just
bringing people from different states and

3077.60.text:
different people from different points in
life we can have a profound impact.

3082.62.text:
I think Janet would agree -- because she said
this -- it is very frustrating that on a city

3087.69.text:
or state level we grapple with this with no
expectation that we can have these meetings

3093.96.text:
on retirement security. And that's so unfortunate.
And that's why conversations like this are

3099.44.text:
worth having among us. Because all of you
are thought leaders. We've got to talk to

3103.75.text:
our different allies and say let's break it
up and let's come together.

3107.44.text:
HUBBARD: Yeah.Bob, I would actually agree
with what Brad said; that you need some sort

3111.22.text:
of central official. In the old Reagan/George
H.W. Bush Administration, there was an economic

3116.20.text:
policy council chaired by the Secretary of
the Treasury. And inside that was a working

3121.49.text:
group on this. And having that kind of structure
I think helps. Because this doesn't naturally

3130.88.text:
QUESTION: (OFF-MIKE). Hello. Yes. Thank you
very much. Mahesh Kotecha. I recently -- well,

3138.74.text:
not so recently listened to Robert Merton
who, you know, was asked what can management

3148.04.text:
- you know, financial know-how - do for -- for
society? He was asked in light of the -- the

3155.94.text:
financial crisis and all of that.
His answer was, let's create a method to empower

3161.14.text:
the pensioner to address the very complex
issue, which is, I want a terminal retirement

3169.24.text:
income that is targeted, that's based on my
willingness to work and save. And how do I

3176.18.text:
choose among all these pension schemes and
investment alternatives that report on stuff

3181.88.text:
that I really don't get an answer on as to
what I care about?

3186.48.text:
I'd like to really ask what is being done
to empower the pensioner to select among the

3192.04.text:
myriad of complex plans that they have. And
I don't hear much about that. I think the

3197.69.text:
technicalities go to the program, the plans
and the investment returns and the like and

3203.80.text:
the actual assumptions. But really, from the
point of view of the consumer, the pensioner,

3208.11.text:
what are we doing to empower them to make
choices that are really pertinent?

3211.69.text:
COWELL: Yeah. Well, I can tell you, because
I run both the health plan and the pension

3216.34.text:
plan in North Carolina, and those are very
important questions. Because as you move to

3221.14.text:
potential hybrid choice systems and get into
more discretion on the part of the pensioner

3227.48.text:
or the health plan consumer, the whole literacy
and education and marketing is critical. And

3235.28.text:
that's -- I will -- it is incredibly difficult.
And I will say in the public sector -- you

3240.20.text:
know, Scott may agree here. It's very difficult
to get the marketing expertise, the communication

3245.65.text: expertise, the dollars to keep up with that.

3248.83.text:
And I see people even making mistakes in their
selections with the basic defined benefit

3254.23.text:
plans. I mean, I'll have a janitor come in
from some rural county who got bad advice

3259.54.text:
from an HR representative and didn't, you
know, select the right beneficiary. And you

3264.98.text:
see the consequences of these, even on a very
simple system.

3268.55.text:
So whatever solution we come to, I think you've
got to design it where there are limited choices

3276.71.text:
and some very good, you know, marketing selection
language. None of that is simple. I think

3283.81.text:
the retirement is easier, maybe, than the
health plan, which I think we're seeing with

3288.00.text:
the national health exchange and others. That's
only one -- that's one facet of the difficulty

3292.29.text:
of these plans. But it's a very important
conversation.

3294.51.text:
STRINGER: And I will tell you that as I move
around the city, I'm constantly having people

3301.03.text:
who are about to retire or who may, in fact,
be in retirement come up to me with a million

3307.16.text:
questions. And they're very concerned. They're
concerned about their pensions. They have

3311.63.text:
a lot of questions. We spend a lot of time
in our community affairs unit actually fielding

3317.20.text:
(inaudible) retiree or potential retirees.
We just -- the mayor's just now negotiated

3322.61.text:
72 percent of our labor contracts. And I cannot
tell you how many people are trying to follow

3330.70.text:
what those contracts mean when you go into
retirement.

3333.35.text:
So we do have -- as reelected officials, we
really do have an obligation to do a very

3337.44.text:
good job explaining to people what their options
are, when should they retire, when should

3342.72.text:
they take money out, what is the different
aspects of this. Because, you know, a mistake

3347.22.text:
can really have real impact, both in terms
of health benefits or pension -- pension opportunity.

3351.57.text:
BELT: I would just note, it's a little bit
different on the private sector side. And

3356.60.text:
I alluded to it with John, kind of the infirmities
or at least oddities of ERISA on the private

3361.56.text:
sector side, is that historically in a defined
benefit plan you had the sponsor making every

3368.37.text:
decision on behalf of the employee. And that
was entirely consistent with their fiduciary

3373.97.text:
responsibility under ERISA. Yet, on the defined
contribution side, it was put out a menu of

3381.61.text:
options but provide no advice and counsel
because of concern about fiduciary liability.

3388.18.text:
It's tough to square that circle. It makes
no sense.

3390.97.text:
Now, post-PPA and some other legislation,
you're providing some safe harbor, so you're

3396.10.text:
starting to get a little bit more information.
But at the end of the day, if the defined

3401.06.text:
benefit plan sponsor of a company thinks that
this structure, these fees, these managers

3406.94.text:
are the best in the defined benefit context,
then they should be able to offer that same

3412.01.text:
option as a default option in defined contribution
context so you could take advantage of that

3417.78.text:
professional management, scale efficiencies,
and everything else. But that hasn't been

3422.38.text:
the way ERISA's been read over the -- until
now.

3425.42.text:
HUBBARD: Time for one last quick question.
Sir, right there.

3431.54.text:
QUESTION: (OFF-MIKE) It's on. Ron Shelp, author
and filmmaker.

3441.47.text:
If I could go back to something that Mr. Stringer
said, but it's indirectly related. Let's say

3447.57.text:
you're a young college student. You're out
of school. You've got a job. It's in the private

3453.44.text:
sector. But you're not on Wall Street, you
never had those aspirations. But you do have

3458.23.text:
an aspiration to have a middle class future,
sort of like your parents had, maybe. But

3466.13.text:
when you look at the salaries they make, even
if they're good salaries, they're almost never

3473.51.text:
My son is in that case. He's been told to
have his IRA, it'll be matched. I personally

3480.19.text:
don't see how over a long career, even if
he changed jobs numerous times, you can possibly

3487.54.text:
save enough money in an IRA, especially with
inflation and other things coming on, to have

3493.67.text: a decent retirement. Any comments, please?

3496.82.text:
STRINGER: I think that -- that is -- that
is part of the larger conversation about retirement

3503.59.text:
security. And it's not just about union workers.
But rather, we should perhaps open up a retirement

3511.66.text:
security to more people to aspire to the middle
class.

3515.23.text:
Look, back in the '60s and '70s, a middle
class family would have one wage earner,you

3522.56.text:
could be a typist, work in manufacturing,
and you could pay the bills and raise your

3528.52.text:
family and you knew you were going to have
a small pension at the end of the day to take

3532.53.text:
care of yourself in your old age.
Today, that's getting much more difficult

3536.99.text:
to aspire to. Here's a challenge in our city.
We talk a lot about raising the minimum wage.

3543.26.text:
I believe we should. But we can't stop there.
We have a high-tech economy that is booming

3549.14.text:
in this city. We have got to prepare our kids
for that opportunity, which means more science,

3555.24.text:
more arts education. And, if we're going rival
Silicon Valley -- we've surpassed Boston -- these

3560.85.text:
are the next generation of middle class jobs
- the coder jobs, the programmer jobs - that

3565.27.text:
will allow our kids to do what their parents
and grandparents have done, which is move

3569.82.text: up the ladder economically in this city.

3573.34.text:
And while I do think there has to be a layer
of retirement security to that -- and there

3577.55.text:
has to be a broader conversation about that
-- one of the failings about the city right

3582.91.text:
now is we are not laying the foundation to
take advantage of these incredible job opportunities

3589.33.text:
and companies that are now in this city and
are telling me -- telling me we do not have

3594.35.text:
the ability to hire local kids in our public
school system because they don't have the

3598.83.text: skills, they're not getting the training.

3601.27.text:
And the way we protect families in the future
is by educating these kids today. These are

3606.72.text:
the future fathers and mothers, and we've
got to make sure they have an opportunity

3611.52.text:
to do what we did and what our grandparents
did. We may be limited in terms of what we

3617.27.text:
accomplish at this moment in our lives. But
we all think our kids have the potential to

3622.59.text:
do anything they want. Especially for me,
I'm fifty-four and I have a three-year-old

3627.32.text:
and a two-year-old. I was up at 3:00 in the
morning, by the way, before coming here. And

3633.11.text:
I worry about what kind of economy is going
to be left for them, retirement security included.

3639.48.text:
COWELL: I would say that politically, there's
a lot more emphasis right now on current cash

3646.16.text:
in hand and wages. I mean, I never thought
that public employees in North Carolina would

3651.10.text:
argue against funding a pension. But I found
out when it came to 'do I get a raise today

3657.13.text:
or do you fund my pension', they'll take the
raise today. So that's a reason why I think

3662.40.text:
this pension issue will not be dealt with
in the immediate term. There's no huge incentive

3666.99.text:
to do it. I do think it's a ticking time bomb
for my generation who do not have the savings

3675.50.text:
COWELL: -- do not have a plan -- our generation.
Ours.

3679.65.text:
COWELL: Ours. So it's -- it's ticking, but
the crisis isn't there yet. And then in the

3688.20.text:
meantime, you've got twenty-year-olds, you
know, with high unemployment, low wage growth

3692.36.text:
for middle class. And that's going be the
more urgent, immediate issue.

3696.15.text:
BELT: And I would simply close on since this
is Council on Foreign Relations, we talked

3700.35.text:
about different models and structures. There's
actually a lot to look at abroad in items

3705.18.text:
of being better educated, whether it's some
of the Scandinavian systems, the superannuation

3709.34.text:
system in Australia, and others that we might
learn from, and it doesn't have to be invented

3714.42.text:
here. So the CFR on a go-forward basis can
do some research and maybe get back to us

3720.05.text:
about what some of these models might be in
their applicability here in the U.S. to help

3725.42.text:
HUBBARD: May our guests never have a pension
closeout. But we're going to have to close

3729.00.text:
out. So thank you. And join me in thanking
the panel.
